qas.question: Which group claims it is Alaska's largest private land owner?
What privelege do private Alaskan corporations have that its public citizens do not?

answers.text: hold title (including subsurface title in many cases

qas.question: Was a law enacted in 1991 allowing corporations to sell land holdings or was it repealed?

answers.text: repealed before they could take effect

qas.question: Which group claims it is Alaska's smallest private land owner?
Which group claims it is Alaska's largest public land owner?

plausible_answers.text: hold title (including subsurface title in many cases

qas.question: What privelege do public Alaskan corporations have that its public citizens do not?

plausible_answers.text: hold title (including subsurface title in many cases

qas.question: What privelege do private Alaskan corporations have that its private citizens do not?

plausible_answers.text: repealed before they could take effect.

qas.question: Was a law enacted in 1919 allowing corporations to sell land holdings or was it repealed?

context: Another 44 million acres (18 million hectares) are owned by 12 regional, and scores of local, Native corporations created under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) of 1971. Regional Native corporation <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>Doyon, Limited<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> often promotes itself as the largest private landowner in Alaska in advertisements and other communications. Provisions of ANCSA allowing the corporations' land holdings to be sold on the open market starting in 1991 were <a2_0><b7_0>repealed before they could take effect<a2_0/>.<b7_0/> Effectively, the corporations <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>hold title (including subsurface title in many cases<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, a privilege denied to individual Alaskans) but cannot sell the land. Individual Native allotments can be and are sold on the open market, however.
